description: Parity indices (female/male, rural/urban, bottom/top wealth quintile and others such as disability status, indigenous peoples and conflict-affected, as data become available) for all education indicators on this list that can be disaggregated

definition.label: Definition
definition.content: Parity indices require data for the specific groups of interest. They represent the ratio of the indicator value for one group to that of the other. Typically, the likely more disadvantaged group is placed in the numerator. A value of exactly 1 indicates parity between the two groups.

rationale.label: Rationale
rationale.content: To measure the general level of disparity between two sub-populations of interest with regard to a given indicator. The further from 1 the parity index lies, the greater the disparity between the two groups of interest.

concepts.label: Concepts
concepts.content: See metadata for relevant underlying indicator.

comments_and_limitations.label: Comments and limitations
comments_and_limitations.content: The indicator is not symmetrical about 1 but a simple transformation can make it so (by inverting ratios that exceed 1 and subtracting them from 2). This will make interpretation easier.

computation_method.label: Computation Method
computation_method.content:
The indicator value of the likely more disadvantaged group is divided by the indicator value of the other sub-population of interest. 
DPI = [Indi]d
[Indi]a
where:
DPI = the Dimension (Gender, Wealth, Location, etc.) Parity Index
Indi = the Education 2030 Indicator i for which an equity measure is needed.
d = the likely disadvantaged group (e.g. female, poorest, etc.)
a = the likely advantaged group (e.g. male, richest, etc.)

disaggregation.label: Disaggregation
disaggregation.content: None because the parity indices directly compare two sub-populations of interest.
